The :group option is broken for multiple fields when performing an AR calculation. See the example below:

```
Account.count(:all, :group => 'firm_id, credit_limit')
# returns <OrderedHash {60=>1, 55=>1, 50=>1, 53=>1}>
# should return <OrderedHash {[2, 60]=>1, [nil, 50]=>1, [9, 53]=>1, [6, 55]=>1, [1, 50]=>1, [6, 50]=>1}>
```

The behavior for grouping by a single field or an association is unchanged. Also, the :group option still takes in a string as always.

text:
ActiveResource currently uses connection level formatter for get requests. This makes it impossible to use custom formatters per resource.

This commit makes the Connection request methods more consistent. It always returns a Response object (instead of sometimes decoding, and sometimes not decoding). The base Resource should decode it using its own configured formatter.

Merging this commit will allow users to add custom formatters on a per Resource basis. The main use case for this is allowing per model handling of _pagination_. This is sorely needed in ActiveResource, and right now its impossible without monkeypatching XmlFormat (PoxPaginate is the best example at the moment).
title: Allow per Resource format settings (will allow pagination with ActiveResource)

comments.text: I like this idea (and I use a similar low-tech helper) but I'm concerned it introduces a broad API for such a simple task. And the API is all at the view level despite being request-wide state, so you can't add attributes in your controller.
@jeremy That's true, we have certainly customized such things from our controllers, I can make that possible. But your comment re: a broad api, has me concerned. What would you like to see instead?
In particular, controller_class_names and merge_tag_attributes aren't general-purpose user-facing API. Maybe they could be singleton methods on the helper (or some other) module.
Also generated classes is way to unspecific. At least they should be scoped somehow, e.g. "controller-whzz-bang action-show" or simliar. Not beautiful, but at least more reliable.
I think this should start out in a plugin first and see what the uptake is.
